expectations:
- MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model A provides 62 chapters covering an exceptionally comprehensive and well-structured curriculum. The progression from foundational concepts (anatomy, cell biology, biophysics) through systems neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience, clinical neuroscience, methods, computational approaches, and career is logical and thorough. Titles are concise and professional (e.g., 'Sistema visual', 'Neuroquímica e sistemas moduladores'). Descriptions are direct, avoid fluff words like 'learn' or 'explore', and pack substantial detail. Unique strengths include dedicated chapters on neuroimunologia, neurofisiologia vascular, epigenética, reprodutibilidade e ciência aberta, neurociência autonômica clínica, and neuroengenharia/BCIs. It covers clinical topics (neurodegeneração, psiquiatria, dor, adicção), advanced methods (optogenética, manipulação de circuitos), computational neuroscience (modelagem, neurodinâmica, ML, IA), and professional skills (gestão de projetos, carreiras, escrita acadêmica, governança). The curriculum is modern with mentions of organoides, connectomics, single-cell multi-omics. It follows vendor neutrality well. No fluff in titles or descriptions. Covers ethics, regulation, and reproducibility. One minor issue: some chapters could arguably be merged (e.g., 'Aprendizagem e plasticidade motora' could be part of motor systems), but the granularity is justified for a mastery-level course. Overall, this is one of the most complete and well-organized outputs.

Model D provides an extremely comprehensive 119-chapter curriculum that is arguably the most granular and detailed of all outputs. It covers everything from evolution of the nervous system, philosophy of mind, detailed neuroanatomy (separate chapters for cortex, subcortical structures, tracts), molecular/cellular neuroscience, multiple chapters on plasticidity, detailed sensory and motor systems, cognition, clinical neuroscience (with separate chapters for stroke, epilepsy, TBI, movement disorders, demyelinating diseases, dementias, depression/anxiety, bipolar/psychoses, addiction, chronic pain), extensive methodology (patch-clamp, multielectrode, EEG, MEG, MRI, PET, fNIRS, microscopy, histology, tracers, optogenetics, CRISPR, iPSC/organoids), computational neuroscience (multiple chapters), statistics (frequentist, Bayesian, causal inference), signal processing, machine learning, deep learning, interpretability, and professional skills. Titles are generally concise. Descriptions are direct and informative. Unique strengths include chapters on neurotoxicology, control theory, psychophysics, computational psychiatry, data management/FAIR standards, and scientific programming. The extreme granularity is both a strength (comprehensive) and a slight weakness (some chapters may be too narrow, e.g., separate chapters for 'Memória de trabalho', 'Memória episódica', 'Memória procedimental' could overwhelm). However, for a mastery-level course, this level of detail is justified. Follows all prompt rules well. Very modern and up-to-date.

Model B provides 62 chapters with excellent coverage. The structure follows a clear progression from cellular/molecular foundations through systems, cognitive, clinical, methods, computational, and applied neuroscience. Titles are mostly concise, though some are slightly verbose (e.g., 'Neurologia Clínica: Outras Doenças Neurológicas', 'Neurociência Computacional: Modelos de Neurônios e Redes'). Descriptions are detailed and informative without excessive fluff, though a few use slightly wordy constructions. Unique strengths include coverage of eixo intestino-cérebro e microbioma, neuroeducação, neuroeconomia/neuromarketing, and terapias avançadas (gene therapy, CRISPR, nanomedicine). The curriculum covers ethics, career, communication, and frontiers well. Some chapter titles mention specific tool abbreviations in descriptions (e.g., 'Allen Brain Atlas, Human Connectome Project' in Bioinformática chapter), which slightly violates vendor neutrality but these are widely known resources. Overall very comprehensive and well-organized, slightly less polished than Models A and D in title conciseness.

Model E provides 76 chapters with very broad coverage. It includes many important topics: cellular/molecular foundations, detailed neuroanatomy (multiple chapters), sensory/motor systems, cognition, development, clinical neuroscience, methods, computational neuroscience, and applied topics. Unique inclusions: neurociência do sexo e gênero, neuroestética, neurociência da criatividade, eixo intestino-cérebro, neurociência do estilo de vida. Titles are generally concise. However, there are some issues: (1) The chapter 'Programação e Análise Computacional' mentions 'Python/R' which could be seen as vendor-specific (though these are widely used tools); (2) Some descriptions use slightly filler-ish language; (3) The organization sometimes feels less cohesive - sensory systems are lumped into one chapter while other areas get excessive granularity (e.g., separate chapters for neuroestética and neurociência da criatividade which are quite niche); (4) Having both 'Neuromodulação Não Invasiva' and 'Estimulação Cerebral Invasiva e Interfaces Neurais' AND 'Interfaces Cérebro-Máquina' creates some redundancy. Despite these issues, the breadth is impressive and it covers most essential topics for mastery.

Model F provides 50 chapters with solid coverage but is less comprehensive than the top models. Titles are concise and professional. Descriptions are well-written and direct. The progression is logical. However, several important areas receive insufficient coverage: (1) Clinical neuroscience is notably thin - only 'Doenças neurológicas' and 'Psiquiatria biológica' for the entire clinical domain, missing dedicated chapters on addiction, pain, neurodevelopmental disorders, aging; (2) Sensory systems are collapsed into a single chapter; (3) Motor systems get only one chapter; (4) Missing dedicated chapters on sleep/circadian rhythms, social cognition, consciousness gets brief treatment; (5) The chapter 'Projeto interdisciplinar e integração' and 'Laboratório prático e técnicas de bancada' feel somewhat like filler/capstone-adjacent content; (6) Statistics gets only one chapter. The vendor neutrality is well maintained. For a mastery-level course, the clinical and cognitive coverage gaps are significant.

Model C provides only 32 chapters, which is significantly less comprehensive than other models. While the content covered is accurate and well-described, major gaps exist: (1) No dedicated chapters on statistics, experimental design, or data analysis; (2) Computational neuroscience gets only one chapter; (3) No chapters on reproducibility, scientific writing, or research management; (4) Clinical coverage is thin (only neurodegenerative diseases, neurodevelopmental disorders, and psychiatry/psychopharmacology); (5) Missing chapters on pain, addiction, aging, sleep in detail; (6) Methods coverage is minimal - neuroimaging and neural recording in one chapter, no microscopy, no histology; (7) No chapters on neuroendocrinology's clinical aspects, stress neurobiology; (8) Missing coverage of epigenetics, proteomics/metabolomics, organoids; (9) Missing governance/regulation chapters. Titles are concise and descriptions are direct. The history chapter's description mentioning 'papiro de Edwin Smith' is a nice touch but the overall curriculum is far too sparse for mastery-level training. The chapter on 'Neuroética e Neurodireito' is a good inclusion.

Model G provides only 33 chapters, making it one of the least comprehensive outputs. While the topics covered are relevant and descriptions are clear, critical gaps exist: (1) Very limited clinical coverage - only neurodegenerative diseases and a combined 'Transtornos Psiquiátricos e do Neurodesenvolvimento' chapter; (2) No dedicated chapters on pain, addiction, epilepsy, stroke, or other major neurological conditions; (3) Methods coverage is thin - optogenética and neuromodulação combined inappropriately in one chapter; (4) No chapters on statistics, experimental design, signal processing; (5) No chapters on scientific writing, research management; (6) No epigenetics/genomics depth, no proteomics; (7) Missing chapters on organoids, CRISPR, histology, microscopy details; (8) Computational neuroscience gets only one chapter; (9) The title 'Optogenética e Neuromodulação' conflates two distinct topics inappropriately. Some descriptions mention specific tools (fMRI, PET, MEG, TMS, tDCS, DBS) but this is acceptable context. The curriculum would not prepare someone for mastery or PhD-level work.

Model D provides an exceptionally comprehensive and granular curriculum (117 chapters) that perfectly aligns with the goal of preparing a learner to be in the 'top 1%' and ready for a PhD. It deeply covers modern neuroscience, including neurobiology, computational methods, statistics (Bayesian, causal inference), programming (Python/R/Git), specific imaging and recording techniques, and professional skills (grant writing, open science, ethics). The titles and descriptions are completely devoid of fluff, concise, and highly professional.

Model E also offers a highly detailed and extensive curriculum (77 chapters). It accurately captures the multidisciplinary nature of neuroscience by including dedicated chapters on programming, statistics, computational models, neuroethics, and career development. It follows all formatting and fluff constraints perfectly. It is slightly less granular than Model D but still an outstanding curriculum.

Model A presents a very strong and rigorous curriculum (62 chapters). It logically progresses from foundational biology to systems, cognition, advanced methodologies (fMRI, EEG, patch-clamp), and professional skills. Titles and descriptions are direct and fluff-free. It provides excellent depth, though slightly less exhaustive than D and E.

Model B is very similar in quality and depth to Model A (63 chapters). It covers all the essential bases of a graduate-level neuroscience education, including bioinformatics, AI, experimental design, and career preparation. It follows all prompt rules regarding conciseness and lack of filler words.

Model F provides a solid curriculum (49 chapters) that hits the major requirements and includes good chapters on lab safety, ethics, and career paths. However, it lacks the extreme granularity and exhaustive depth required to truly stand out as the 'most comprehensive curriculum in the world' for top 1% mastery when compared to the higher-ranked models.

Model G offers a well-formatted curriculum with no fluff, but at 33 chapters, it reads more like an undergraduate survey course rather than a comprehensive path to top 1% mastery and PhD readiness. It lacks the deep methodological, computational, and statistical rigor found in the top models.

Model C is very similar to Model G (32 chapters). While it strictly follows the formatting and style rules (no fluff, concise descriptions), it completely misses the mark on comprehensiveness. It lumps too many advanced topics together, failing to provide the extensive depth expected for a curriculum aiming to create the 'Einstein' of the field.

Mais completo e moderno, com progressão clara do básico ao avançado, cobrindo fundamentos, sistemas, métodos, estatística/causalidade, neuroinformática, técnicas (EEG/MEG/MRI/PET, microscopia, opto/quimiogenética, iPSC/organoides), clínica e tendências. Inclui ética, bem-estar animal, reprodutibilidade, gestão de dados e carreira. Linguagem PT-BR e descrições majoritariamente diretas, com boa neutralidade; pequenas quedas por alguns termos em inglês (single-cell, sorting) e densidade alta, mas dentro do aceitável.

Currículo amplo e bem estruturado, forte em métodos (estatística, desenho experimental, ciência aberta), modalidades de medida/manipulação e translacional/clínico, além de IA/BCI e tendências. Boa concisão e PT-BR. Pontos a melhorar: alguns anglicismos (“internal models”, “machine learning”, “circuit mapping”), e faltam alguns tópicos de base/operacionais que D cobre melhor (psicometria/psicofísica em mais detalhe, neurotoxicologia/ambiente, programação/HPC mais explícitos). Ainda assim, excelente.

Cobertura forte e relativamente completa, com bom equilíbrio entre neurobiologia, cognição, métodos, computacional/IA, clínica, ética/regulação, práticas de laboratório e tendências. Progressão adequada e descrições em geral objetivas. Perde pontos por misturar termos em inglês em títulos/descrições ("Neural engineering", "big data", "deep learning") e por granularidade menor que A/D em alguns blocos (psicometria, causalidade, conectômica/metodologias avançadas).

Muito bom em conteúdo clássico (celular, sistemas, cognição, clínica) e inclui tendências (microbioma, organoides, neuromórfica/VR) e carreira. Porém, viola fortemente a diretriz de evitar fluff nas descrições (usa repetidamente “Origens”, “Relação com…”, tom mais introdutório), inclui vários nomes de recursos/vendor-like em descrição (Allen Brain Atlas, Human Connectome Project) e algumas escolhas de escopo/título ficam longas. Métodos quantitativos (estatística/causalidade/reprodutibilidade) existem, mas menos profundos que os melhores.

Bem abrangente e atualizado, com muitos tópicos modernos (ômicas, organoides, CRISPR, IA, conectômica) e inclui carreira e comunicação científica. Perde pontos por diversas violações de estilo: descrições e títulos com termos de “introdução” e listagens longas, alguma redundância (interfaces cérebro-máquina em múltiplos capítulos), e alguns termos/nomes específicos (DREADD, CRISPR-Cas9) são aceitáveis como técnicas, mas a escrita fica menos vendor-neutra e menos concisa. Ainda assim, sólido.

Cobertura boa para um curso geral, mas insuficiente para nível de maestria/topo: métodos quantitativos, desenho experimental, reprodutibilidade, análise de dados e computacional aparecem de forma superficial; faltam capítulos dedicados a genética/ômicas modernas, iPSC/organoides, conectômica avançada, psicometria/psicofísica, governança de dados e prática científica. Há também erro conceitual no título “Optogenética e Neuromodulação” com descrição que não inclui optogenética (só TMS/tDCS/DBS).

Conteúdo muito resumido (poucos capítulos) para a exigência de currículo “extenso” e para preparar para projetos complexos/PhD. Falta profundidade em métodos (estatística, desenho experimental, reprodutibilidade), técnicas modernas (single-cell, conectômica, iPSC/organoides), análise de dados/ML, regulação, governança e tendências. Também usa termos em inglês em descrição (LTP/LTD, PET scan) e tem pouca granularidade clínica/metodológica.
